fullText: This production of Coward's 1930 comedy of sexual manners proves that even the most scintillating dialogue can't save a show when its stars seem to be performing in different plays.
dtliExcerpt: This production of Coward's 1930 comedy of sexual manners proves that even the most scintillating dialogue can't save a show when its stars seem to be performing in different plays.
bwwExcerpt: The show mostly steers clear of sourness because of our awareness of a redeeming self-consciousness in Amanda and Elyot. Even when these two are going at it hammer and tongs, you have the sense of their watching themselves, on some level, and being elegantly amused by their inelegant behavior. In this version of Coward's soign√©e world, pratfalls are at least as important as poses.
